Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions that coincide exactly with rain detections indicate strong rainfall integration
Description: If irrigation is consistently reduced whenever rain is detected, the system properly uses rainfall signals to pause watering.
short rationale: Reductions align with rain; operational integration, low privacy risk.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases occurring during long gaps between rain detections indicate dry weather dominance
Description: When rain events are rare and weather logs show more irrigation boosts, the system responds to extended dry periods.
short rationale: Dry gaps drive boosts; operational trend only.

Inference: Weather-based reductions occurring even during brief rain detections suggest conservative or highly sensitive rainfall response
Description: Even small rain events trigger irrigation pauses, showing the system prioritizes rainfall heavily.
short rationale: Sensitive rain response; operational logic exposure, low privacy impact.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during periods with frequent rain detections indicate conflicting triggers or unregistered soil saturation
Description: If the system boosts watering despite rain detections, other dryness cues or logic layers may override rainfall inputs.
short rationale: Boosts despite rain expose conflicting logic/overrides; operational behavior exposure.

Inference: Clusters of weather-based reductions aligning with clusters of rain detections indicate extended wet-season conditions
Description: When both logs show sustained reductions and rainfall, prolonged wet weather is present.
short rationale: Wet-season pattern; operational/climate signal.

Inference: Weather-based reductions without corresponding rain detections suggest forecast-based rainfall anticipation
Description: The system might predict incoming rain and reduce irrigation before actual rain is detected.
short rationale: Forecast-driven reductions before rain; reveals predictive control behavior.

Inference: Rain detections followed by weather-based reductions with delay indicate system reacts after confirming rainfall
Description: The delay suggests rainfall must persist or reach a threshold before irrigation is modified.
short rationale: Delayed reaction shows threshold/confirmation; mild operational detail.

Inference: Weather-based reductions occurring before rain detections indicate predictive weather logic
Description: The system may reduce watering based on forecasted precipitation before the rain sensor registers actual rainfall.
short rationale: Pre-rain cuts expose forecast/anticipatory control timing.

Inference: Weather-based increases during low-frequency rain detection periods reflect an active dry-season irrigation strategy
Description: With few rain events and many weather-driven increases, the system compensates for dryness.
short rationale: Boosts in dry periods; operational trend only.

Inference: Weather reductions immediately stopping irrigation during heavy rain detection bursts show strong water-saving efficiency
Description: High rainfall density results in clear and immediate irrigation suppression.
short rationale: Immediate stop in heavy rain; operational efficiency signal.

Inference: Rain detections that do not trigger weather-based reductions indicate misalignment between systems
Description: If rainfall is sensed but irrigation is not reduced, configuration or communication issues may exist.
short rationale: No reduction despite rain reveals misconfiguration/integration gap.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases during periods of no rain detections suggest controlled irrigation independent of rainfall
Description: The system determines dryness primarily from weather parameters rather than rainfall.
short rationale: Irrigation driven by weather without rain; operational pattern only.

Inference: Weather reductions that coincide with strong rain detection clusters confirm redundant validation of rainfall conditions
Description: Both systems independently identify wet conditions and jointly reduce irrigation.
short rationale: Redundant validation between logs; low privacy exposure.

Inference: Weather reductions paired with rain detections during nighttime indicate nocturnal rainfall patterns
Description: Nighttime logs reflect rainfall-driven watering pauses at night.
short rationale: Nighttime rain-driven cuts; minor contextual exposure.

Inference: Rain detections occurring without any weather-based adjustments imply rainfall intensity too weak to adjust irrigation
Description: Light drizzle or mist triggers sensors but is insufficient to warrant watering changes.
short rationale: Light rain below threshold; operational threshold insight.

Inference: Weather-based reductions exceeding the number of rain detections suggest rainfall forecasting is more influential than actual rainfall
Description: Forecast models may trigger irrigation cuts even when rainfall is limited.
short rationale: Forecast models overriding rain detections; exposes configuration/behavior.

Inference: Periods of weather-driven increases without rain detections reflect strong atmospheric dryness signals
Description: Dry wind, heat, or humidity drops are prompting irrigation boosts independently of rainfall data.
short rationale: Dryness-driven boosts without rain; operational trend only.

Inference: Rain detections occurring shortly after weather-based reductions validate predictive rainfall-based irrigation logic
Description: The system accurately anticipates rainfall before it is detected.
short rationale: Reductions before rain later validated; reveals predictive control behavior.

Inference: Repeated weather-based reductions during frequent rain detections indicate saturated climate cycles
Description: High rainfall frequency leads to continuous irrigation suppression.
short rationale: Frequent rain leads to repeated cuts; operational/climate signal.

Inference: Weather-driven irrigation increases during sparse rain detections reflect early onset of a dry season
Description: As rainfall declines, irrigation boosts become more common.
short rationale: Boosts as rain declines; operational trend.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation reductions during rain detection gaps may imply lingering wetness from earlier rainfall
Description: The system reduces watering even without new rain because residual conditions still warrant it.
short rationale: Cuts during gaps show residual wetness assumption; low privacy risk.

Inference: Weather-based increases with no rain detections but with long dry intervals suggest the system tracks rainfall deficit
Description: Absence of rain over time triggers irrigation boosts to compensate for cumulative dryness.
short rationale: Long dry deficit triggers boosts; operational pattern only.

Inference: Weather-based reductions that occur across multiple zones simultaneously with rain detections show uniform storm coverage
Description: All zones respond equally to widespread rainfall events.
short rationale: Uniform cross-zone cuts; low-risk site context.

Inference: Weather-based increases occurring only in certain zones while rain detections are uniform indicate uneven weather–zone logic calibration
Description: Some zones respond more strongly to dryness despite equal rain detection.
short rationale: Zone-specific response despite uniform rain exposes calibration/logic differences.

Inference: Rain detections concentrated in short bursts causing immediate irrigation reductions indicate threshold-based rainfall logic
Description: Sensors trigger reductions once rainfall surpasses a specific minimum intensity or duration.
short rationale: Burst thresholds trigger cuts; operational logic signal.

Inference: Rain detections with no reduction in irrigation but later weather-based reductions suggest indirect influence of rainfall on weather models
Description: Rainfall may indirectly alter weather parameters later, causing reductions.
short rationale: Indirect effect delayed via weather models; low privacy exposure.

Inference: Weather-based increases during periods of high rain detection variability indicate difficulty distinguishing between rain events and dry gaps
Description: Frequent alternation between wet and dry signals prompts irrigation increases during short dry intervals.
short rationale: Boosts amid variable rain show sensitivity to short dry gaps; operational trend.

Inference: Weather reductions continuing long after rain detections stop indicate extended moisture assumptions
Description: The system assumes the environment remains wet for longer than rain duration alone would suggest.
short rationale: Extended wetness assumption; operational tuning only.

Inference: Rain detections followed by weather-based increases suggest rainfall too weak to alter drying trends
Description: Light rain fails to stop dryness-driven irrigation boosts, so weather logic increases watering anyway.
short rationale: Light rain insufficient; operational boost context.

Inference: Weather-based reductions that occur whenever rain detections exceed a threshold indicate rainfall accumulation logic
Description: Multiple or heavy rain events trigger stronger irrigation cutbacks.
short rationale: Threshold-based accumulation cutbacks; operational logic signal.

Inference: Weather-based irrigation increases in zones without rain detection indicate microclimate or sensor placement differences
Description: One area may be dry while another detects rainfall.
short rationale: Zone-level differences reveal microclimate/sensor placement; minor profiling.

Inference: Rain detections without weather-based reductions but with later increases indicate environmental moisture misinterpretation
Description: The system may treat rainfall as too insignificant to impact irrigation, then boosts watering later.
short rationale: Rain seen but considered insufficient, later boosts; operational context.

Inference: Strong alignment of weather-based reductions with every rain detection indicates ideal rainfall responsiveness
Description: The system reacts consistently and proportionally to rainfall events.
short rationale: Perfect alignment; operational efficiency, low privacy risk.

Inference: Weak alignment between rain detection and irrigation reductions indicates opportunity for improved rain–weather integration
Description: Rainfall detection is not effectively influencing irrigation behavior.
short rationale: Weak linkage reveals integration gap; low privacy exposure.

Inference: Weather-driven increases following long periods without rain detections reveal cumulative atmospheric dryness trends
Description: Dry months show boosts in irrigation as the system compensates for lack of rainfall.
short rationale: Long dry spells drive increases; operational trend.

Inference: Weather-driven reductions that occur before, during, and after rain detections reflect robust multi-stage rainfall handling
Description: The system responds to rainfall throughout the entire rain cycle, not just on detection.
short rationale: Multi-stage response; operational robustness only.
